persons.name: Johann WilhelmRitter
persons.description: German physician and natural philosopher.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
persons.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

persons.name: Christoph HeinrichPfaff
persons.description: German physician, chemist and physicist who worked on animal electricity alongside Volta and Humboldt. The younger brother of mathematician Johann Friedrich Pfaff.

persons.name: PaulErman
persons.description: German physician and physicist. He was mainly interested in electricity and magnetism and was the first recipient of the Volta Prize. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: ProclusLycius
persons.description: Last major Greek Neoplatonist philosopher.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: Otto deGuericke
persons.description: German man of science, politican and inventor, who invented the first air pump and showed the power of a vacuum.

persons.name: FrancisHauksbee
persons.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: StephenGray
persons.description: English chemist, who worked on electricity. FRSL.

persons.name: Charles Francois de Cisternay duFay
persons.description: French chemist and superintedent of the Jardin du Roi, who worked on electricity. ForMemRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

persons.name: Pieter vanMusschenbroek
persons.description: Dutch natural philosopher who invented the Leyden Jar. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: StephenGray
persons.description: English chemist, who worked on electricity. FRSL.

persons.description: French chemist and superintedent of the Jardin du Roi, who worked on electricity. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Ewald Georg vonKleist
persons.description: German speaking lawyer and natural philosopher who invented a form of the Leyden jar.

persons.name: AndreasCunaeus
persons.description: Dutch lawyer who experimented with the Leyden Jar.

persons.name: Pieter vanMusschenbroek
persons.description: Dutch natural philosopher who invented the Leyden Jar. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Rene-AntoineRéaumur
persons.description: French entomologist who developed a widely used temperature scale. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamWatson
persons.description: Natural philosopher who worked on electrostatics. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: PeterCollinson
persons.description: Cloth merchant, gardener and botanist and part of a trans-Atlantic correspondence network. FRSL.

places.name: Philadelphia
places.description: the most populous city in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: Franz Ulrich TheodorAepinus
persons.description: German born natural philosopher who mostly worked in Russia. Best known for his researches, theoretical and experimental, in electricity and magnetism.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamStukeley
persons.description: Anglican clergyman, physician, significant antiquary natural philosopher and a friend of Newton's. FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AntioneNollet
persons.description: French clergyman and natural philosopher specialising in electrostatics. ForMemRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: William Stukeley

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnCanton
persons.description: An experimental natural philosopher and teacher, especially in the field of electricity. FRSL.

persons.name: Giovanni BattistaBeccaria
persons.description: Italian physicist, particularly the study of electricity. ForMemRSL

works.name: The History and Present State of Electricity
works.author: Joseph Priestley

persons.name: Georg WilhelmRichmann
persons.description: Russian physicist (of German Baltic origin)

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Franz KarlAchard
persons.description: Prussian chemist who found how to extract sugar from beet.

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: AbrahamBennet
persons.description: Natural philosopher and close associate with Priestley, Darwin and Wedgwood. He recorded atmospheric electricity. FRSL.

persons.name: AbrahamBennet
persons.description: Natural philosopher and close associate with Priestley, Darwin and Wedgwood. He recorded atmospheric electricity. FRSL.

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: PaulErman
persons.description: German physician and physicist. He was mainly interested in electricity and magnetism and was the first recipient of the Volta Prize. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Martin vanMarum
persons.description: Dutch physician, natural philosopher, and inventor; Director of the Dutch Society of Sciences. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilhelmHisinger
persons.description: Swedish physicist and chemist who collaborated with Jöns Jacob Berzelius.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: JohnCuthbertson
persons.description: English-born scientific instrument maker who spent much of his career in the Netherlands. Working with Van Marum, he developed glass-plated frictional electrical machines.

persons.name: Christoph HeinrichPfaff
persons.description: German physician, chemist and physicist who worked on animal electricity alongside Volta and Humboldt. The younger brother of mathematician Johann Friedrich Pfaff.

persons.name: ImmanuelKant
persons.description: Professor of Logic and Metaphysics at the University of Königsberg. Regarded as the most important philosopher of the eighteenth century.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: DavidHartley
persons.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnLocke
persons.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis JacquesThénard
persons.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: WilliamHarvey
persons.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).
